name: Dodona
shortDescription: Ancient oracle of Zeus in Epirus where priestesses interpreted divine will through rustling oak leaves
fullDescription: Dodona was Zeus's oracle sanctuary in Epirus, northwestern Greeceâ€”arguably Greece's oldest oracle, predating even Delphi. The site centered on a sacred oak grove where priestesses called Selli (or Peleiades, 'doves') interpreted Zeus's messages through the rustling of oak leaves, the cooing of doves, and the ringing of bronze vessels. According to legend, Zeus's first oracle began when two black doves flew from Egyptian Thebesâ€”one to Dodona, one to the oracle of Ammon in Libya. The sanctuary's rustic simplicity contrasted with Delphi's grandeur, reflecting Zeus's role as both sky god and protector of agriculture. Pilgrims consulted Dodona on matters ranging from personal concerns to state affairs, receiving responses through the sacred oaks' voice.
